channel.title: Projects on Anna Kurtin
channel.description: Recent content in Projects on Anna Kurtin

item.title: Comp Bio Project 2 Kurtin
item.description: Introduction The data that I am using for this project comes from the Primate Molecular Ecology and Evolution Lab, with permission for use from Dr. Anthony Di Fiore. This data documents information about monkeys that were tranquilized at the Tiputini Biodiversity Station to take biological samples and place a tracking collar on the animal. There are 21 observations, meaning that there were a total of 21 monkeys darted. The columns included in this dataset are as follows:

item.title: Kurtin Comp Bio Project 1: Exploratory Data Analysis
item.description: Mexican Waterfowl Count Data Across Two Two-Year Periods from iNaturalist For my project, I am using data exported from iNaturalist, one of the largest platforms for citizen science. This data is interesting to me becuase citizen science platforms such as iNaturalist have recently been recognized for their valuable potential for science. Mobilizing every day people to collect data on the natural world has provided scientists with an unprecedented ability to monitor biodiversity on different spatial scales.

item.title: Central Texas Spring Salamanders
item.description: This paper was my final term paper for Field Herpetology. In it, I review existing scientific knowledge of the salamanders of central texas (genus Eurycea), how these species are affected by urbanization, and the policies in place concerning their protection. As someone who spent most of my childhood in Central Texas, this issue is near and dear to me. Read on to find out more about one of the most unique animal groups of this region!

item.title: Fall Undergraduate Research Symposium 2020 Science Slam
item.description: “Science Slams” are short videos explaining research to the general public. Check out my video below, where I talk about my current research investigating the bioacoustics of howler monkey calls:

item.title: Principles of Animal Behavior Final Project
item.description: This paper examines the relationship between male dominance and alternate reproductive strategies in swordtail fish. All videos used for this project are from The Cummings Lab.
